fields.summary: USER-CONSOLE: Redirect http:// url to https:// when SSL is enabled

fields.description:
When SSL is enabled, which is the default setup when installed from packages, redirect the http:// request URL to https:// automatically. 

Related article:

http://ace.mu.nu/archives/334783.php

"Next, and this part I find mind-boggingly absurd, the web address was located at "https://www.whateveritwas.com/orca". Notice the "s" after http. This denotes it's a secure connection, something that's used for e-commerce and web-based email. So far, so good. The problem is that they didn't auto-forward the regular "http" to "https" and as a result, many people got a blank page and thought the system was down."
fields.summary: USER-CONSOLE: Redirect http:// url to https:// when SSL is enabled

comments.body: We need to check if we can change the port and have that take effect.   If so, that's a reasonable workaround to this problem.  Otherwise we'll need to resolve this issue.

Isn't port 80 (HTTP) and port 443 (HTTPS) the de facto port for production (IANA official standard)? I understand it can be changed, but by default, if port number isn't specified, should we default to port 80 and port 443? 

Reference:

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_TCP_and_UDP_port_numbers

*Under 'Well-known ports'*

{code}
80	TCP		Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP)	Official
443	TCP		HTTPS (Hypertext Transfer Protocol over SSL/TLS)	Official
{code}

Another question: since we have Web Services that Eucalyptus uses, would it be beneficial for us to register with IANA for ports 8773, (CC) 8774, and (NC)8775?

Thoughts?

Since the CLC puts the web front end on 8443 and API endpoints on 8773, I didn't want to assume we should use standard ports. :-/

Normally, when you install app servers, they run someplace in the 8000 range. This is mainly (I think) to avoid conflicts with the many things that could run http servers. It makes the administrator make conscious decisions on what's running on the standard ports.

I think if we look at the way tornado was intended to run in production, we find that you'd have nginx on port 80 and/or 443. Then, you'd have 1-N tornado processes running on other ports (like in the 8000 range) and they're all being fed traffic through nginx. This is the scenario I think we should encourage as well, but we haven't done anything formal there. I think this needs to be tested out and blogged about (or something more formal).
Something is going to have to listen on port 80 so it can do the redirecting.  Setting up a little web server like nginx that does this sounds like a great knowledge base article.
Adding web server on port 80 was one of the options that UI team discussed. I think we agreed that this will not be done automatically but should be added as best practice into documentation.

As we have documented this, and determined we're not going to listen on port 80, is this a "will not fix" or are there other solutions?
Asking [~kyolee] and [~vasya]

The whole thing is discussed here: https://github.com/facebook/tornado/issues/523
I did also find a patch we could apply to make this work. We'd need to evaluate that. The discussion in the link favors an external solution (like via nginx or something else in front of tornado). To "just work", we should probably have an optional redirect that defaults to being enabled. I can find a evaluate that patch.
I think we don't have to do any special tricks if user requesting http on https port.

I've looked at the options out there and they are basically about patching tornado. One thing I'll look at is firing up an additional tornado instance to listen on port 80 and redirect to the configured port/protocol the main instance listens on. I don't think maintaining tornado patches is what we want to be doing.

Attempting to use tornado as a redirect server within the same process as our main tornado thread won't work. Tornado's main classes aren't thread safe and we'd need to run this in a separate process space. [~mspaulding] would prefer not doing this and I tend to agree. I believe writing a simple redirect server would be simple and I think I can leverage a built-in simple http server in python to do this.
I think I'll need to extract the request host to use in the redirect. I'll finish this once I can test in QA.
This is not working when CLC and console are colocated.
Talked with Neil and we're going to leave this redirector turned off by default. I'm adding a documentation task for this (if I didn't already).
